module.title: How the Web Works
module.description: Understand the fundamentals of networking and client-server communication

lessons.title: Client-Server Model
lessons.content:
# Essential to know
- The web is based on client-server architecture
- Client = your browser (requests data)
- Server = computer that sends back data
- Communication happens via HTTP/HTTPS protocol

---

# Client-Server Model Explained

## What is a Client?

The **client** is any application that requests data. Most commonly:
- **Your web browser** (Chrome, Firefox, Safari)
- Mobile apps
- Desktop applications

When you type `google.com` in your browser, your browser becomes the **client** asking for Google's homepage.

## What is a Server?

The **server** is a computer that:
- **Stores** data (HTML files, images, videos, databases)
- **Listens** for requests from clients
- **Sends back** the requested data

Servers run 24/7 waiting for requests.

## How They Communicate

```
Client (Browser)  â”€â”€â”€[Request]â”€â”€â”€>  Server
                                    (processes)
Client (Browser)  <â”€â”€â”€[Response]â”€â”€  Server
```

**Example:**
1. You type `example.com` in your browser
2. Your browser sends a request: "Give me the homepage"
3. The server finds the HTML file
4. The server sends it back
5. Your browser displays it

## Real-World Analogy

**Restaurant:**
- You (client) ask the waiter for food
- Kitchen (server) prepares it
- Waiter brings it back to you

The waiter is like HTTP - the protocol that carries messages!

## Key Points

âœ… Client **requests**, server **responds**
âœ… One server can handle thousands of clients
âœ… Clients and servers can be anywhere in the world
âœ… Communication follows strict rules (protocols)

lessons.title: Understanding URLs
lessons.content:
# Essential to know
- URL = Uniform Resource Locator (web address)
- Made of parts: protocol, domain, port, path, query
- Each part has a specific purpose
- Understanding URLs helps debug issues

---

# URLs Demystified

## What is a URL?

A **URL** is the address of a resource on the web. Like a postal address, but for the internet!

## Anatomy of a URL

Let's break down:
```
https://www.example.com:443/products/shoes?color=red&size=42#reviews
```

### 1. Protocol (`https://`)
- **HTTP** = HyperText Transfer Protocol (not secure)
- **HTTPS** = HTTP Secure (encrypted, safe) ðŸ”’
- **Other protocols**: `ftp://`, `ws://` (WebSocket)

**Always prefer HTTPS!**

### 2. Domain (`www.example.com`)
- The **name** of the server
- Translated to an IP address by DNS
- `www` is a subdomain (optional)
- `example.com` is the main domain

### 3. Port (`:443`)
- Usually **hidden**
- Default for HTTP: `80`
- Default for HTTPS: `443`
- Custom: `:3000`, `:8080` (for development)

### 4. Path (`/products/shoes`)
- The **specific resource** on the server
- Like folders: `/products/shoes/nike`
- The server decides what to return

### 5. Query Parameters (`?color=red&size=42`)
- **Extra information** sent to the server
- Start with `?`
- Multiple params separated by `&`
- Format: `key=value`

**Example use cases:**
- Search: `?q=react+tutorial`
- Filters: `?category=books&price=low`
- Pagination: `?page=2`

### 6. Fragment (`#reviews`)
- **Jumps to a section** on the page
- Processed by the browser, not sent to server
- Used for navigation within a page

## Common URL Patterns

**Static page:**
```
https://example.com/about
```

**API endpoint:**
```
https://api.example.com/v1/users
```

**With authentication:**
```
https://example.com/dashboard?token=abc123
```

**Development:**
```
http://localhost:3000/
```

## Tips

âœ… Read URLs to understand what page you're on
âœ… Query params can be modified manually
âœ… HTTPS = safe, HTTP = not safe for sensitive data

lessons.title: HTTP Requests & Responses
lessons.content:
# Essential to know
- HTTP is the protocol for web communication
- Main methods: GET (read), POST (create), PUT (update), DELETE (remove)
- Status codes tell you what happened (200 OK, 404 Not Found, 500 Error)
- Request has headers, body; Response has headers, body, status

---

# HTTP: The Language of the Web

## What is HTTP?

**HTTP** (HyperText Transfer Protocol) is how browsers and servers talk to each other.

Think of it as the **rules of conversation** between client and server.

## HTTP Methods (Verbs)

Different types of requests:

### GET - "Give me data"
```
GET /users/123
```
- **Read** data
- No body
- Can be bookmarked
- Example: Loading a webpage, fetching user profile

### POST - "Create something new"
```
POST /users
Body: { "name": "Alice", "email": "alice@example.com" }
```
- **Create** new resource
- Has a body with data
- Example: Sign up form, creating a blog post

### PUT - "Update this"
```
PUT /users/123
Body: { "name": "Alice Smith" }
```
- **Replace** entire resource
- Example: Update user profile

### PATCH - "Change part of this"
```
PATCH /users/123
Body: { "email": "newemail@example.com" }
```
- **Partially update** resource
- Only send what changed

### DELETE - "Remove this"
```
DELETE /users/123
```
- **Remove** resource
- Example: Delete account, remove item

## HTTP Status Codes

The server's response always includes a **status code**:

### 2xx - Success âœ…
- **200 OK** - Request succeeded
- **201 Created** - New resource created
- **204 No Content** - Success, but no data to return

### 3xx - Redirect ðŸ”€
- **301 Moved Permanently** - Resource moved to new URL
- **302 Found** - Temporary redirect

### 4xx - Client Error âŒ
- **400 Bad Request** - Invalid request
- **401 Unauthorized** - Need to log in
- **403 Forbidden** - Logged in but no permission
- **404 Not Found** - Resource doesn't exist

### 5xx - Server Error ðŸ’¥
- **500 Internal Server Error** - Server crashed
- **502 Bad Gateway** - Server can't reach another server
- **503 Service Unavailable** - Server temporarily down

## Request Structure

```http
POST /api/users HTTP/1.1
Host: example.com
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer token123

{"name": "Alice", "age": 25}
```

**Parts:**
1. **Method & Path**: POST /api/users
2. **Headers**: Metadata (content type, auth)
3. **Body**: The actual data

## Response Structure

```http
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Content-Type: application/json

{"id": 1, "name": "Alice", "age": 25}
```

**Parts:**
1. **Status**: 200 OK
2. **Headers**: Metadata
3. **Body**: The data you requested

## Common Headers

**Request Headers:**
- `Content-Type`: Format of the body (`application/json`)
- `Authorization`: Authentication token
- `Accept`: What format you want back

**Response Headers:**
- `Content-Type`: Format of response
- `Set-Cookie`: Save data in browser
- `Cache-Control`: How long to cache

## HTTPS vs HTTP

**HTTP** = Plain text (anyone can read)
**HTTPS** = Encrypted (secure) ðŸ”’

**Always use HTTPS for:**
- Passwords
- Personal data
- Payment info

lessons.title: APIs & REST Explained
lessons.content:
# Essential to know
- API = Application Programming Interface (how programs talk to each other)
- REST = style of building APIs using HTTP
- RESTful APIs use standard HTTP methods and URLs
- JSON is the most common data format

---

# APIs: Making Programs Talk

## What is an API?

**API** = A way for one program to use another program's features.

**Think of it as a menu at a restaurant:**
- You don't need to know how to cook
- You just order from the menu
- The kitchen (API) does the work
- You get your food (data)

## Real Examples

**Weather App:**
```
Your app â†’ Weather API â†’ Gets current temperature
```

**Login with Google:**
```
Your app â†’ Google API â†’ Authenticates user
```

**Stripe Payments:**
```
Your app â†’ Stripe API â†’ Processes payment
```

## What is REST?

**REST** = Representational State Transfer

It's a **style** of building APIs using HTTP in a standard way.

### REST Principles

**1. Resource-based URLs**
```
/users          (collection)
/users/123      (specific user)
/users/123/posts (user's posts)
```

**2. Use HTTP methods correctly**
- GET `/users` â†’ List all users
- GET `/users/123` â†’ Get user 123
- POST `/users` â†’ Create new user
- PUT `/users/123` â†’ Update user 123
- DELETE `/users/123` â†’ Delete user 123

**3. Stateless**
Each request contains all needed information. Server doesn't remember previous requests.

**4. Return standard status codes**
- 200 = Success
- 404 = Not found
- 500 = Server error

## RESTful API Example

**Blog API:**
```
GET    /posts           â†’ List all posts
GET    /posts/5         â†’ Get post #5
POST   /posts           â†’ Create new post
PUT    /posts/5         â†’ Update post #5
DELETE /posts/5         â†’ Delete post #5
GET    /posts/5/comments â†’ Get comments on post #5
```

## Request & Response

**Request:**
```http
GET /api/users/123
Authorization: Bearer token
```

**Response:**
```json
{
  "id": 123,
  "name": "Alice",
  "email": "alice@example.com",
  "posts": 42
}
```

## Why JSON?

**JSON** (JavaScript Object Notation) is the standard format because:
- âœ… Easy to read
- âœ… Lightweight
- âœ… Works with all languages
- âœ… Native to JavaScript

```json
{
  "user": {
    "name": "Alice",
    "age": 25,
    "active": true,
    "hobbies": ["coding", "gaming"]
  }
}
```

## API Authentication

**Ways to secure APIs:**

**1. API Key**
```http
GET /api/data
X-API-Key: abc123xyz
```

**2. Bearer Token (JWT)**
```http
GET /api/data
Authorization: Bearer eyJhbGc...
```

**3. OAuth**
Complex but very secure (used by Google, Facebook)

## REST vs Other API Styles

**REST** - Simple, standard, HTTP-based
**GraphQL** - Query exactly what you need
**gRPC** - Fast, for microservices
**SOAP** - Old, XML-based, very formal

## When to Use REST

âœ… Standard CRUD operations
âœ… Public APIs
âœ… Simple data fetching
âœ… Web and mobile apps

## Quick Tips

ðŸ“Œ Use plural nouns: `/users` not `/user`
ðŸ“Œ Use nesting for relationships: `/users/123/posts`
ðŸ“Œ Version your API: `/v1/users`
ðŸ“Œ Return helpful error messages
ðŸ“Œ Document your API!

lessons.title: DNS: Finding Websites
lessons.content:
# Essential to know
- DNS = Domain Name System (phonebook of the internet)
- Translates domain names (google.com) to IP addresses (172.217.14.206)
- Your browser asks DNS servers: "Where is example.com?"
- Makes the web user-friendly (easier than memorizing numbers)

---

# DNS: How Browsers Find Websites

## The Problem

Computers communicate using **IP addresses**:
```
172.217.14.206  â† Google's IP address
```

But humans prefer **names**:
```
google.com  â† Much easier to remember!
```

**DNS solves this problem.** It's like a phonebook for the internet.

## What is DNS?

**DNS** = Domain Name System

It **translates** human-friendly names into computer-friendly numbers.

```
You type: google.com
DNS translates: 172.217.14.206
Your browser connects to: 172.217.14.206
```

## How DNS Works (Step by Step)

When you type `example.com` in your browser:

### 1. Browser Cache
"Have I visited example.com recently?"
- If YES: Use cached IP address (fast!)
- If NO: Ask DNS

### 2. DNS Resolver (Your ISP)
"Dear DNS, where is example.com?"

Your internet provider's DNS server tries to help.

### 3. Root Server
If resolver doesn't know, it asks the **root servers**:
"Who handles .com domains?"

Root server responds: "Ask the .com nameserver"

### 4. TLD Server (.com)
"Dear .com server, where is example.com?"

TLD server responds: "Ask example.com's nameserver"

### 5. Authoritative Server
"What's the IP for example.com?"

Finally! The answer: `93.184.216.34`

### 6. Browser Connects
Now your browser can connect to the right server!

All of this happens in **milliseconds**.

## DNS Record Types

DNS stores different types of records:

**A Record** - Points to IPv4 address
```
example.com â†’ 93.184.216.34
```

**AAAA Record** - Points to IPv6 address
```
example.com â†’ 2606:2800:220:1:248:1893:25c8:1946
```

**CNAME** - Alias for another domain
```
www.example.com â†’ example.com
```

**MX Record** - Mail server
```
example.com â†’ mail.example.com
```

**TXT Record** - Text info (used for verification)
```
example.com â†’ "verification=abc123"
```

## Common DNS Servers

**Google DNS:**
- `8.8.8.8`
- `8.8.4.4`

**Cloudflare DNS:**
- `1.1.1.1`
- `1.0.0.1`

**Your ISP's DNS** (default)

## DNS Caching

To speed things up, DNS responses are **cached**:

1. **Browser cache** (few minutes)
2. **OS cache** (varies)
3. **Router cache** (varies)
4. **ISP cache** (hours/days)

This is why DNS changes take time to propagate worldwide ("DNS propagation").

## TTL (Time To Live)

Each DNS record has a **TTL** value:
```
example.com  TTL 3600  93.184.216.34
```

TTL = 3600 seconds (1 hour)

This tells caches: "You can store this for 1 hour, then ask again."

## Why DNS Matters for Developers

**1. Deploying websites**
You need to configure DNS records to point to your server.

**2. Debugging**
"Why isn't my site working?" â†’ Often DNS issues

**3. Performance**
DNS lookup adds latency to requests

**4. Security**
DNS can be hijacked (use DNSSEC)

## DNS Tools

**Check DNS records:**
```bash
nslookup example.com
dig example.com
```

**Check from multiple locations:**
- whatsmydns.net
- dnschecker.org

## Fun Facts

ðŸŒ There are 13 root DNS servers (actually hundreds of copies)
âš¡ DNS was invented in 1983
ðŸ” HTTPS also needs DNS to work
ðŸ“ DNS can be used for geolocation

exercises.title: Client or Server?
exercises.description: Identify whether each component is a client or server.
exercises.instructions: For each scenario, determine if the component is acting as a CLIENT or SERVER.

questions.question: Your web browser requesting a webpage
questions.explanation: The browser is requesting data, making it the client.

questions.question: A computer at AWS hosting your website
questions.explanation: It's storing and serving data to visitors, so it's the server.

questions.question: Your mobile app fetching weather data
questions.explanation: The app is requesting data from a weather service, making it the client.

questions.question: A database responding to queries
questions.explanation: The database serves data to applications that query it.

exercises.title: URL Breakdown
exercises.description: Identify the parts of a URL.
exercises.instructions:
Given this URL, identify each component:

https://shop.example.com:443/products/shoes?color=red&size=10#reviews

questions.question: What is the protocol?
questions.explanation: https:// is the protocol, indicating a secure connection.

questions.question: What is the domain?
questions.explanation: shop.example.com is the full domain (subdomain + main domain).

questions.question: What is the path?
questions.explanation: /products/shoes is the path to the resource.

questions.question: What are the query parameters?
questions.explanation: Everything after ? and before # are query parameters.

questions.question: What is sent to the server?
questions.explanation: The fragment (#reviews) is only used by the browser, not sent to the server.

exercises.title: HTTP Methods & Status Codes
exercises.description: Match HTTP methods and status codes to scenarios.
exercises.instructions: Choose the correct HTTP method or status code for each scenario.

questions.question: You want to fetch a list of blog posts. Which method?
questions.explanation: GET is used to retrieve/read data without modifying it.

questions.question: You're submitting a signup form. Which method?
questions.explanation: POST is used to create new resources, like a new user account.

questions.question: You're editing your profile. Which method?
questions.explanation: PATCH is best for partial updates. PUT would replace the entire resource.

questions.question: The page loaded successfully. Which status code?
questions.explanation: 200 OK means the request succeeded and returned the data.

questions.question: You created a new blog post. Which status code should the server return?
questions.explanation: 201 Created indicates a new resource was successfully created.

questions.question: You tried to access /users/99999 but that user doesn't exist. Which status code?
questions.explanation: 404 Not Found means the requested resource doesn't exist.

exercises.title: RESTful API Design
exercises.instructions: Which API endpoint design follows REST best practices?

questions.question: Getting all users:
questions.explanation: GET /users follows REST conventions: plural noun, GET method for reading.

questions.question: Getting user with ID 42:
questions.explanation: GET /users/42 uses the ID in the path, which is RESTful.

questions.question: Creating a new blog post:
questions.explanation: POST /posts is the RESTful way to create a resource in a collection.

questions.question: Deleting post with ID 5:
questions.explanation: DELETE /posts/5 uses the proper HTTP method and resource path.

questions.question: Getting comments for post 10:
options: Both A and B are acceptable
questions.explanation: Both patterns are valid. B shows relationship better, A is simpler for filtering.

questions.question: What does DNS stand for?
questions.explanation: DNS = Domain Name System, the internet's phonebook.

questions.question: What does DNS translate?
questions.explanation: DNS translates human-friendly names (google.com) to IP addresses (172.217.14.206).

questions.question: Which DNS record points a domain to an IP address?
questions.explanation: A record maps a domain name to an IPv4 address.

questions.question: What is 8.8.8.8?
questions.explanation: 8.8.8.8 is Google's public DNS server, free for anyone to use.

questions.question: Why do DNS changes take time to propagate?
questions.explanation: DNS records are cached at multiple levels (browser, ISP, etc.) for performance.
